a) GERTRUDE BRIDERICK: "Since we are not legally liable
for accidents or mishaps to workshop or seminar Participants.
I favor rescinding the action taken at Columbus. That action,
as I recall, was prompted by advice from our Assistant
Executive Director that we were legally liable. I am
inclined to sustain the action taken with respect to a £25,000-
limit travel policy on the NAEB Executive Director, Associate
Director, Television Engineer, NAEB Officers and committee
members while traveling on NAEB business and expense. The
fact that the Executive Director and his Associate are covered
by a University of Illinois policy does not relieve us of
our obligation, in my opinion, unless we exclude all others
who may have coverage of one kind or another.”
b) VERNON BRONSON: "No insurance for seminars but the
resolution to cover employees officers and directors. Covers
a moral obligation. Insists this carried through."
c) R. J. COLEMaN: 1) I do not favor taking out insurance
on workshops and seminars if we are not legally liable. I also
suggest that we cancel the proposed insurance on the upcoming
TV /Management Seminar. Most of the participants will be
covered by their institutions anyhow and NAEB does not have
the money for this purpose if it is not a necessary expenditure.
?) I am in favor of taking out group insurance to cover those
not covered by their own institutions (such as Bidlack). I
find that, in my own case, if I get travel authorization
from the University even though the trip is not at University
Expense, this is considered as in line of duty and therefore
comes under University coverage. I feel sure that this same
pertains to most institutions from which our officers and
Board members come. What I am saying is this: I favor a
minimum expenditure unless or until NAEB has more money to spend
that it now does."
d) JACK MCBRIDE: "If funds are made available to permit
taking out an insurance policy for the August television
management seminar, then I recommend this be so done. However,
I would not want to see the seminar watered down greatly
because of the financial burden imposed, especially since we
have no legal obligation. In general, my feeling is that while
there is no legal obligation but a moral obligation as pointed
out by Leonard Marks, we should take out insurance on the
August seminar. I recommend that this same question be included
on the agenda at the St. Louis Board meeting for considerable
discussion. I therefore recommend that the Executive Director
investigate and determine costs for a blanket liability
